facts.text: Civil Appeal No. 401 of 1964 filed in Supreme Court.

anchor.surface_text: CIVIL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Civil Appeal No. 401 of 1964.

facts.text: Appeal by special leave from Mysore High Court judgment dated October 14, 1963 in N.F.A. No. 139 of 1963 and M.F.A. No. 141 of 1963.

anchor.surface_text: Appeal by special leave from the judgment and order dated October 14, 1963, of the Mysore High Court in N.F.A. No. 139 of 1963 and M.F.A. No. 141 of 1963.

facts.text: Election held to Bangalore South Scheduled Castes constituency in February 1962.

anchor.surface_text: An election was held to the Bangalore South  Scheduled Castes  companystituency in February 1962.

facts.text: Four persons contested election including appellant and Munichinnappa (respondent No. 1).

anchor.surface_text: Four persons stood for election including the appellant and Munichinnappa respondent No. 1,

facts.text: Munichinnappa (respondent No. 1) obtained highest votes and declared elected.

anchor.surface_text: who obtained the highest number of votes and was declared elected.

facts.text: Appellant filed election petition challenging election of respondent No. 1.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant then filed an election petition challenging the election of respondent No. 1 on a number of grounds.

facts.text: Petitioner claimed respondent No. 1 was Voddar by caste, not a scheduled caste in Constitution Scheduled Castes Order 1950.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant on the other hand companytended that respondent No. 1 was a Voddar by caste and that Voddar was number a scheduled caste specified in the Order

facts.text: Respondent No. 1 claimed to belong to scheduled caste Bhovi listed in the Order.

anchor.surface_text: Respondent No. 1 claimed that he belonged to the scheduled caste listed as Bhovi in the Order.

facts.text: Election Tribunal held Bhovi is a sub-caste of Voddars, only sub-caste included, respondent No. 1 not Bhovi, ineligible.

anchor.surface_text: The Election Tribunal held that the caste mentioned as Bhovi in the Order was a subcaste amongst the Voddars and that only this sub- caste was included in the Order and number the entire Voddar caste.

facts.text: Election Tribunal set aside election and ordered re-election.

anchor.surface_text: Consequently the election was set aside and re-election ordered by the Tribunal.

facts.text: Respondent No. 1 appealed to Mysore High Court.

anchor.surface_text: Respondent No. 1 went in appeal to the High Court

facts.text: Mysore High Court held Voddar caste same as Bhovi in Order based on 1950 circumstances, allowed appeal, dismissed election petition.

anchor.surface_text: The High Court held that Voddar caste as such was number included in the Order, but companysidering the facts and circumstances in existence at the time when the Order was passed in 1950, the Bhovi caste mentioned therein was numberother than Voddar caste.

facts.text: High Court refused leave to appeal to Supreme Court.

anchor.surface_text: The High Court having refused leave to appeal,

facts.text: Supreme Court granted special leave.

anchor.surface_text: the appellant got special leave from this Court,

facts.text: No caste known as Bhovi in Mysore State before 1956 reorganisation, undisputed.

anchor.surface_text: the fact  which was number disputed before the High Court  that in the Mysore State as it was before the re-organisation of 1956 there was numbercaste known as Bhovi at all.

facts.text: Resolution passed by Voddar caste at conference in July 1944 to change name to Bhovi.

anchor.surface_text: It seems that a resolution was passed by the Voddar caste ,at a companyference in July 1944 in which it was resolved that the name of that caste be changed from Voddar to Bhovi.

facts.text: Mysore Government order dated February 2, 1946 directing community known as Vodda to be called Boyi in government communications.

anchor.surface_text: Eventually an order was passed on February 2, 1946 in these terms Government are pleased to direct that the companymunity known as Vodda be in future called Boyi in all Government companymunications and records.

facts.text: Since 1946, Voddar caste known as Boyi in government records; Voddar and Vodda same.

anchor.surface_text: Since then it seems that in all government records the Voddar caste has been known as Boyi, for it is number disputed that Voddar and Vodda are the same.

facts.text: Constitution Scheduled Castes Order 1950 issued after consultation with Rajpramukh of Mysore.

anchor.surface_text: when the President made the Order in 1950 after companysultation with the Rajpramukh of Mysore

facts.text: Supreme Court held respondent No. 1, though Voddar by caste, belongs to scheduled caste Bhovi in the Order.

anchor.surface_text: we agree with the High Court that respondent No. 1 though Voddar by caste belongs to the scheduled caste of Bhovi mentioned in the Order.

facts.text: Voddar caste spelt variously as Boyi, Bovi, Bhovi in English after 1946.

anchor.surface_text: the High Court has held that ever since the Order of 1946, the Voddar caste has been variously spelt as Boyi, Bovi, and Bhovi in English,

facts.text: No caste specifically known as Bhovi in Mysore before 1956, necessitating evidence to identify.

anchor.surface_text: But when it is number disputed that there was numbercaste specifically known as Bhovi in the Mysore State before 1956, the only companyrse open to companyrts to find out which caste was meant by Bhovi is to take evidence in that behalf.

facts.text: Mysore Government notification February 2, 1946 spelt Voddar as Voddara, Yoddar, Vodda.

Appeal by special leave from the judgment and order dated October 14, 1963, of the Mysore High Court in N.F.A. No. 139 of 1963 and M.F.A. No. 141 of 1963.

In the present appeal we are concerned only with one ground, namely, that respondent No. 1 was not a member of any of, the scheduled castes mentioned in the Constitution Scheduled Castes Order, 1950 hereinafter referred to as the Order. Respondent No. 1 claimed that he belonged to the scheduled caste listed as Bhovi in the Order.

concepts.interpretation: The Order specifies the castes deemed Scheduled Castes; respondent No. 1 claimed Bhovi, petitioner disputed equating to Voddar not listed.

interpretation_anchor.surface_text: ded in the Order and number the entire Voddar caste. The Tribunal also held that respondent No. 1 did number belong to the sub-caste of Bhovi and ther

concepts.unlisted_description: Presidential notification under Article 341 listing castes, races or tribes deemed Scheduled Castes for a State

anchor.surface_text: The main contention on behalf of the appellant is that a person is only entitled to stand for election from a scheduled caste constituency if he is a member of a caste specified in the Order and that it is not open to any one to claim that though he is not a member of a caste specified in the Order and is a member of some other caste, that other caste is included in the caste specified in the Order. It is submitted that wherever a caste has more than one name, the Order specifies the other name in brackets and that even where a particular caste is spelt in more than one way, the Order has included in the same entry the various spellings of the same caste. Therefore, as the caste Bhovi specified in the Order does not mention the caste Voddar in brackets thereafter, it was not open to the Tribunal to take evidence to the effect that Voddar caste is no other than the Bhovi caste. It is therefore urged that the High Court was wrong in looking into the evidence that was produced before the Tribunal and then coming to the conclusion that the caste Bhovi mentioned in the Order was meant for the caste Voddar and that such evidence should not have been allowed by the Tribunal. If such evidence had not been allowed the respondent who is a Voddar by caste could not stand for election for the Voddar caste is not mentioned in the Order at all. Article 341 of the Constitution which deals with Scheduled Castes is as follows- The President may with respect to any State or Union territory, and where it is a State, after consultation with the Governor thereof, by public notification, specify the castes, races, or tribes or parts of or groups within castes, races or tribes which shall for the purposes of this Constitution be deemed to be Scheduled Castes in relation to that State or Union territory, as the case may be. Parliament may by law include in or exclude from the list of Scheduled Castes specified in a notification issued under clause (1) any caste, race or tribe or part of or group within any caste, race or tribe, but save as aforesaid a notification issued under the said clause shall not be varied by any subsequent notification.

concepts.interpretation: Provides for finality of the Presidential notification specifying Scheduled Castes, modifiable only by Parliament; generally no evidence allowed to alter or expand the list, but exception permitted where no caste by that name existed to identify the intended caste based on historical evidence and circumstances at the time of notification.

interpretation_anchor.surface_text: ch was number disputed before the High Court  that in the Mysore State as it was before the re-organisation of 1956 there was numbercaste known as Bho

concepts.unlisted_description: Power of President to notify Scheduled Castes after consultation with Governor; final unless amended by Parliament

anchor.surface_text: The difficulty in the present case arises from the fact which was not disputed before the High Court that in the Mysore State as it was before the re-organisation of 1956 there was no caste known as Bhovi at all. The Order refers to a scheduled caste known as Bhovi in the Mysore State as it was before 1956 and therefore it must be accepted that there was some caste which the President intended to include after consultation with the Rajpramukh in the Order, when the Order mentions the caste Bhovi as a scheduled caste. It cannot be accepted that the President included the caste Bhovi in the Order though there was no such caste at all in the Mysore State as it existed before 1956. But when it is not disputed that there was no caste specifically known as Bhovi in the Mysore State before 1956, the only course open to courts to find out which caste was meant by Bhovi is to take evidence in that behalf.

concepts.interpretation: Courts may admit evidence to determine the identity of a caste named in the Scheduled Castes Order when undisputed that no such caste existed by that name in the relevant state at the time, to ascertain the intended caste based on contemporaneous facts and government records.

concepts.interpretation: Voddar caste deemed included as Bhovi based on historical name change and government records.

Respondent No. 1 claimed that he belonged to the scheduled caste listed as Bhovi in the Order.

issues.text: whether a person is only entitled to stand for election from a scheduled caste constituency if he is a member of a caste specified in the Order and that it is not open to any one to claim that though he is not a member of a caste specified in the Order and is a member of some other caste, that other caste is included in the caste specified in the Order

anchor.surface_text: The main contention on behalf of the appellant is that a person is only entitled to stand for election from a scheduled caste constituency if he is a member of a caste specified in the Order and that it is not open to any one to claim that though he is not a member of a caste specified in the Order and is a member of some other caste, that other caste is included in the caste specified in the Order. It is submitted that wherever a caste has more than one name, the Order specifies the other name in brackets and that even where a particular caste is spelt in more than one way, the Order has included in the same entry the various spellings of the same caste.

issues.text: whether in the peculiar circumstance that there was no caste known as Bhovi in the Mysore State before 1956, courts can take evidence to find out which caste was meant by Bhovi in the Order

anchor.surface_text: The difficulty in the present case arises from the fact which was not disputed before the High Court that in the Mysore State as it was before the re-organisation of 1956 there was no caste known as Bhovi at all. The Order refers to a scheduled caste known as Bhovi in the Mysore State as it was before 1956 and therefore it must be accepted that there was some caste which the President intended to include after consultation with the Rajpramukh in the Order, when the Order mentions the caste Bhovi as a scheduled caste.

issues.text: whether the difference in spelling (Bhovi vs Boyi) in the Order and government records prevents holding that Voddar caste is the Bhovi scheduled caste

anchor.surface_text: It is however urged that the Order does not mention the caste Boyi but the caste Bhovi and that wherever there is a difference in spelling of the same caste, the Order has provided for that also see for example, Bhambi, Bhambhi, Shenva, Chenva etc. Therefore when the Order provided the inclusion of the caste Bhovi therein it could not refer to Voddar caste, for the change of name that was sanctioned by the then government of Mysore in 1946 was from Voddar to Boyi.

arguments.claim: A person is only entitled to stand for election from a scheduled caste constituency if a member of a caste specified in the Order; cannot claim another caste is included via evidence, as Order uses brackets for synonyms and lists spelling variants.

anchor.surface_text: The main contention on behalf of the appellant is that a person is only entitled to stand for election from a scheduled caste constituency if he is a member of a caste specified in the Order and that it is not open to any one to claim that though he is not a member of a caste specified in the Order and is a member of some other caste, that other caste is included in the caste specified in the Order. It is submitted that wherever a caste has more than one name, the Order specifies the other name in brackets and that even where a particular caste is spelt in more than one way, the Order has included in the same entry the various spellings of the same caste.

anchor.surface_text: In the circumstances therefore we agree with the High Court that respondent No. 1 though Voddar by caste belongs to the scheduled caste of Bhovi mentioned in the Order.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Undisputed absence of Bhovi caste pre-1956 necessitated evidence; 1944 resolution and 1946 government order renaming Voddar to Boyi/Bhovi, spelling variations in records, and consultation with Rajpramukh support identification of Voddar as intended Bhovi.

holdings.text: the only course open to courts to find out which caste was meant by Bhovi is to take evidence in that behalf.

anchor.surface_text: But when it is not disputed that there was no caste specifically known as Bhovi in the Mysore State before 1956, the only course open to courts to find out which caste was meant by Bhovi is to take evidence in that behalf.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Article 341 mandates finality of Presidential notification, but where no caste by listed name existed in the state at notification time, evidence required to identify intended caste to avoid absurdity of including non-existent caste.

holdings.text: it is not open to make any modification in the Order by producing evidence to show for example that though caste A alone is mentioned in the Order, caste B is also a part of caste A and therefore must be deemed to be included in caste A.

anchor.surface_text: It may be accepted that it is not open to make any modification in the Order by producing evidence to show  for example  that though caste A alone is mentioned in the Order, caste B is. also a part of caste A and therefore must be deemed to be included in caste A.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Article 341(1) specifies castes by notification after consultation; clause (2) limits variation to parliamentary law only, providing finality; Order uses brackets for synonyms and lists spelling variants.

holdings.text: the High Court was right in the peculiar circumstances of the present case in not attaching any importance to difference in spelling in English, and to treat Bhovi as the same as Boyi.

anchor.surface_text: the High Court therefore has not attached any importance to the change in the English spelling in the peculiar circumstances of this case. In this connection attention may be drawn to the notification of the then government of Mysore dated February 2, 1946 where Voddar caste is spelt in three ways in the same notification

holdings.reasoning_summary: Post-1946 records show Voddar variously spelt as Boyi, Bovi, Bhovi in English despite same Kannada equivalent; same 1946 notification spells Voddara, Yoddar, Vodda; another copy Vaddara, Bovis; no undue weight to English spelling when no Bhovi caste existed.

holdings.text: But for this fact it would not have been open to any party to give evidence to the effect that  for- example  caste A mentioned in the Order includes or was the same as caste B where caste A does exist in the area to which the Order applies.

anchor.surface_text: We may again repeat that we have referred to the evidence in this case only because there was undoubtedly no caste known as Bhovi in the Mysore State as it was before 1956 and we had to find out therefore which caste was meant by the word Bhovi as used in the Order. But for this fact it would not have been open to any party to give evidence to the effect that  for- example  caste A mentioned in the Order includes or was the same as caste B where caste A does exist in the area to which the Order applies.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Reiterates general rule of no evidence for expansion where listed caste exists, distinguishing the instant exception.

But when it is not disputed that there was no caste specifically known as Bhovi in the Mysore State before 1956, the only course open to courts to find out which caste was meant by Bhovi is to take evidence in that behalf.
In the circumstances therefore we agree with the High Court that respondent No. 1 though Voddar by caste belongs to the scheduled caste of Bhovi ment

It may be accepted that it is not open to make any modification in the Order by producing evidence to show  for example  that though caste A alone is mentioned in the Order, caste B is. also a part of caste A and therefore must be deemed to be included in caste A.
In the circumstances therefore we agree with the High Court that respondent No. 1 though Voddar by caste belongs to the scheduled caste of Bhovi ment

anchor.surface_text: the High Court therefore has not attached any importance to the change in the English spelling in the peculiar circumstances of this case.
